awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Impact of early social adversity on brain structure in primates
awd_abstract_narration:
Early social adversity can shape an individual’s brain and behavior across the lifespan, but how these negative experiences exert their influence remains poorly understood. This doctoral dissertation project investigates the relationship between early life environment and aspects of microscopic brain anatomy in two nonhuman primate species. The research leverages existing primate brain collections to advance knowledge about early life stressors, brain, and behavior, and provides broader comparative context for research on similar processes in humans. The project supports graduate research and training in STEM and provides laboratory training and mentoring opportunities to undergraduate students who will have an active role in the research. The investigators plan to share these results with broad audiences via publications, conference talks, and science engagement activities with the public.

In early life, young individuals of many species rely on their mothers or caregivers to provide emotional support and to teach them the skills needed to thrive. Past research has indicated that adult animals who experienced separation from their mothers or caregivers at a young age exhibit anatomical differences in their brains such as significant increases in the size of some brain areas and tracts that connect these structures. Notably, the parts of the brain that are most affected make up the reward circuit, which functions to promote learning and motivate behaviors. Consequently, these anatomical differences in the brain could contribute to the development of social and cognitive deficits associated with early social adversity. The main objective of this project is to investigate at the microscopic level how rearing environment in early life can result in long-term structural changes of the reward circuit. The investigators use existing primate brain collections to compare individuals with different rearing histories across two species that are thought to vary in terms of neural plasticity. In each of these brains, the investigators perform analyses to visualize and quantify 1. connections made between neurons, 2. morphology of neurons, and 3. receptor expression of neurons. With these data, the investigators can begin to describe the mechanisms behind changes in brain structure as a result of early social adversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Although analyzing and writing results is still in progress, this study builds off current research, which indicates that early life adversity may result in atypical connectivity patterns among areas of the brain's reward circuit. To investigate further, we are examining the microanatomical differences in the reward circuit of adult mother-reared and nursery-reared primates.   

Children worldwide are reared in aversive settings that can include neglect, parental loss or parental maladjustment, leaving them susceptible to emotional, social, and cognitive deficits. This project provides neuroanatomical evidence for how these behavioral deficits could manifest. These data have the potential to inform the development of early life interventions. Furthermore, this project focuses on the reward circuit, which is involved in several neurological diseases including depression, addiction, autism, and dementia. Results from this study have translational value in understanding the etiology of these diseases. 

Additionally, the present study may provide clues into how the human brain evolved to drive prosocial behaviors. Recent studies have provided evidence for a unique neurochemical profile in a critical area of the reward circuit (the nucleus accumbens), which is also a region of interest in the present study. This unique neurochemical profile is hypothesized to facilitate social conformity behaviors, decreased aggression, and enhanced awareness of social signals. By investigating long-term microanatomical changes of the nucleus accumbens in the context of early life experience, we can better understand how plasticity in the brain permits the development of prosocial behaviors.  

Broader Impacts

Co-PI Miller has focused on mentoring an undergraduate student from The George Washington University, Amy Longtin, who is now pursuing a doctorate at Vanderbilt University. Co-PI Miller actively taught her anthropological and neuroscience theory, trained her in laboratory techniques and gave her an active role in performing experiments for this project. Amy Longtin did an undergraduate honors thesis using this primate sample to investigate potential changes in synapse density and cellular distributions of the insular cortex.

Additionally, throughout the present project, staining and RNAscope experiments in long-fixed primate tissue have been optimized. These protocols will be shared with any interested researchers to encourage this type of useful research.

Finally, this project has generated collections of Nissl-stained, synaptophysin-stained, and TH-stained primate tissue series for future students to perform their own investigations regarding the long-term effects of early life adversity. 

In addition to working on the funded project, co-PI Miller has published related research: 

M.A. Raghanti, E.N. Miller, D. Jones, H.N. Smith, E.N. Munger, M.K. Edler, K.A. Phillips, W.D. Hopkins, P.R. Hof, C.C. Sherwood, and C.O. Lovejoy (2023) Hedonic eating, obesity, and addiction result from increased neuropeptide Y in the nucleus accumbens during human brain evolution. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences USA 120: e2311118120.

 

E.N. Miller and C.C. Sherwood (2023) Brain, cognition, and behavior in humans and other primates. In: A Companion to Biological Anthropology, 2nd Edition. C.S. Larsen (ed.), Wiley-Blackwell Publishing. pp. 329-343.

 

E.N. Miller, P.R. Hof, C.C. Sherwood, and W.D. Hopkins (2021) The paracingulate sulcus is a unique feature of the medial frontal cortex shared by great apes and humans. Brain, Behavior and Evolution 96: 26-36.

 

K. Hirter, E.N. Miller, C.D. Stimpson, K.A. Phillips, W.D. Hopkins, P.R. Hof, C.C. Sherwood, C.O. Lovejoy, and M.A. Raghanti (2021) The nucleus accumbens and ventral pallidum exhibit greater dopaminergic innervation in humans compared to other primates. Brain Structure and Function 226: 1909-1923.
